Text

Just upon [the border of [Wales]1-wales]61-the border of wales , but within [one of [the English counties]63-the english counties]62-one of the english counties , there is [a cluster of hills]64-a cluster of hills , rising [one above the other in gradual slopes]65-one above the other in gradual slopes , until the summits form [a long , broad tableland]66-a long , broad tableland , many miles across . [This tableland]67-this tableland is not so flat that all of it can be seen at once , but here and there are little dells , shaped like deep basins , which [the country folk]68-the country folk call hollows ; and every now and then there is a rock or hillock covered with yellow gorse bushes , from the top of which can be seen [the wide , outspread plains]69-the wide , outspread plains , where hundreds of sheep and ponies are feeding , which belong to [the farmers and [cottagers]71-cottagers dwelling in [the valley below]72-the valley below]70-the farmers and cottagers dwelling in the valley below . Besides [the chief valley]73-the chief valley , which divides [the mountains]74-the mountains into two groups , and which is broad enough for [a village]75-a village to be built in , there are [long , narrow glens]76-long , narrow glens , stretching up into [the very heart of the tableland]77-the very heart of the tableland , and draining away the waters which gather [there by]78-there by the melting of snow in the winter and the rain of thunderstorms in summer . Down [every glen]79-every glen flows a noisy mountain stream , dashing along [its]80-its rocky course with so many tiny waterfalls and impatient splashes , that the gurgling and bubbling of brooks come up even into the quietness of [the tableland]81-the tableland and mingle with the singing of the birds and the humming of the bees among the heather . There are not many paths across [the hills]82-the hills , except the narrow sheep - walks worn by the tiny feet of the sheep as [they]83-they follow one another in long , single lines , winding in and out through the clumps of gorse ; and [few people]84-few people care to explore [the solitary plains]85-the solitary plains , except [the shepherds who have the charge of the flocks]86-the shepherds who have the charge of the flocks , and [tribes of village children who go up every summer to gather the fruit of the wild and hardy bilberry wires]87-tribes of village children who go up every summer to gather the fruit of the wild and hardy bilberry wires . [The whole of [this broad tableland]89-this broad tableland]88-the whole of this broad tableland , as well as [the hills]82-the hills , are common pasture for [the inhabitants of [the valleys]92-the valleys]91-the inhabitants of the valleys , who have an equal right to keep sheep and ponies on [the uplands]93-the uplands with [the lord of the manor]94-the lord of the manor . But the property of [the soil]95-the soil belongs to [the latter]96-the latter , and [he]96-the latter only has the power of enclosing the waste so as to make [fields]97-fields and plant woods upon it , provided always that [he]96-the latter leaves a sufficient portion for the use of [the villagers]98-the villagers . In times gone by , however , when [the lord of the manor]94-the lord of the manor and [[his]94-the lord of the manor agent]100-his agent were not very watchful , it was the practice of [poor persons]101-poor persons , who did not care how uncomfortably [they]101-poor persons lived , to seek out [some distant hollow]102-some distant hollow , or the farthest and most hidden side of [a hillock]103-a hillock , and there build [themselves]101-poor persons such a low , small hut , as should escape the notice of [any passer - by]104-any passer - by , should [they]101-poor persons chance to go that way . Little by little , making low fences which looked like [the surrounding gorse bushes]105-the surrounding gorse bushes , [they]101-poor persons enclosed small portions of [the waste land]106-the waste land , or , as it is called , encroached upon [the common]107-the common ; and if [they]101-poor persons were able to keep [their]101-poor persons encroachment without having [their]101-poor persons hedges broken down , or if [the lord of the manor]94-the lord of the manor neglected to demand rent for [it]109-it for the space of twenty years , [[their]101-poor persons fields and [gardens]111-gardens]110-their fields and gardens became securely and legally [their]101-poor persons own . Because of this right , therefore , are to be found here and there [little farms of three or four fields a - piece]112-little farms of three or four fields a - piece , looking like islands , with [the wide , open common around [them]112-little farms of three or four fields a - piece]113-the wide , open common around them ; and some miles away over [the breezy uplands]114-the breezy uplands there is even [a little hamlet of [these poor cottages]116-these poor cottages]115-a little hamlet of these poor cottages , all belonging to [the people who dwell in them]117-the people who dwell in them . Many years ago , even many years before [my]0-i story begins , [a poor woman]118-a poor woman — who was far worse off than [a widow]119-a widow , for [[her]118-a poor woman husband]120-her husband had just been sentenced to transportation for twenty - one years — strayed down to [these mountains]121-these mountains upon [her]118-a poor woman sorrowful way home to [[her]118-a poor woman native place]122-her native place . [She]118-a poor woman had [[her]118-a poor woman only child]123-her only child with [her]118-a poor woman , [a boy five years of age]124-a boy five years of age ; and from some reason or other , perhaps because [she]118-a poor woman could not bear to go [home]125-home in shame and disgrace , [she]118-a poor woman sought out a very lonely hiding - place among [the hills]82-the hills , and with [her]118-a poor woman own hands reared rough walls of turf and stones , until [she]118-a poor woman had formed such a rude hut as would just give shelter to [her]118-a poor woman and [[her]118-a poor woman boy]127-her boy . There [they]128-they lived , uncared for and solitary , until [the husband]129-the husband came back , after suffering [his]129-the husband twenty - one years ' punishment , and entered into [a little spot of land entirely [his]129-the husband own]1311-a little spot of land entirely his own . Then , with the assistance of [[his]129-the husband son]1312-his son , [a strong , full - grown young man]1313-a strong , full - grown young man , [he]129-the husband rebuilt [the cottage]1314-the cottage , though upon a scale not much larger or much more commodious than [[[his]129-the husband wife]1315-his wife 's old hut]1316-his wife 's old hut . Like [other groups of mountains]1317-other groups of mountains , the highest and largest are [those near the centre]1318-those near the centre , and from [them]1318-those near the centre [the land]1319-the land descends in lower and lower levels , with smaller hills and [smoother valleys]1320-smoother valleys , until at length [it]1319-the land sinks into [the plain]1321-the plain . Then they are almost like [children]1322-children 's hills and [valleys]1323-valleys ; the slopes are not too steep for very little feet to climb , and [the rippling brooks]1324-the rippling brooks are not in so much hurry to rush on to [the distant river]1325-the distant river , but that [boys]1326-boys and [girls at play]1327-girls at play can stop [them]1324-the rippling brooks for a little time with slight banks of mud and stones . In just such [a smooth , sloping dell , down in [a soft green basin]1329-a soft green basin , called [Fern 's Hollow]2-fern 's hollow]1328-a smooth , sloping dell , down in a soft green basin , called fern 's hollow , was the hiding - place where [[the convict]1330-the convict 's sad wife]1331-the convict 's sad wife had found an unmolested shelter . [This dwelling]1332-this dwelling , the second one raised by [the returned convict]1333-the returned convict and [[his]1333-the returned convict son]1312-his son , is built just below [the brow of [the hill]1336-the hill]1335-the brow of the hill , so that the back of [the hut]1337-the hut is formed of [the hill]1336-the hill itself , and only the sides and front are real walls . These walls are made of rubble , or loose , unhewn stones , piled together with a kind of mortar , which is little more than clay baked hard in the heat of the sun . The chimney is a bit of old stove - pipe , scarcely rising above the top of [the hill]1336-the hill behind ; and , but for the smoke , [we]1340-we could look down the pipe , as through the tube of a telescope , upon [the family sitting round the hearth within]1341-the family sitting round the hearth within . The thatch , overgrown with moss , appears as a continuation of the slope of [the hill]1336-the hill itself , and might almost deceive the simple sheep grazing around it . Instead of a window there is only a square hole , covered by a shutter when the light is not urgently needed ; and the door is so much too small for [its]1337-the hut sill and lintels as to leave large chinks , through which adventurous bees and beetles may find their way within . [You]1343-you may see at a glance that there is but [one room]1344-one room , and that there can be no up - stairs to [the hut]1337-the hut , except that upper storey of [the broad , open common behind [it]1337-the hut , where the birds sleep softly in their cosy nests]1346-the broad , open common behind it , where the birds sleep softly in their cosy nests . Before [the house]1347-the house is [a garden]1348-a garden ; and beyond that [a small field sown with silver oats]1349-a small field sown with silver oats , which are dancing and glistening in the breeze and sunshine ; while before [the garden]1350-the garden wicket , but not enclosed from [the common]107-the common , is [a warm , sunny valley]1352-a warm , sunny valley , in the very middle of which a slender thread of [a brook]1353-a brook widens into a lovely little basin of a pool , clear and cold , the very place for [the hill ponies]1354-the hill ponies to come and drink . Looking steadily up [this pleasant valley]1355-this pleasant valley from the threshold of [the cottage]1314-the cottage , [we]1340-we can just see a fine , light film of white smoke against the blue sky . Two miles away , right down off [the mountains]74-the mountains , there is [a small coal - field]1358-a small coal - field and [a quarry of limestone]1359-a quarry of limestone . In [a distant part of [the country]1361-the country]1360-a distant part of the country there are large tracts of land where coal and iron pits are sunk on every side , and [their]74-the mountains desolate and barren pit - banks extend for miles round , while a heavy cloud of smoke hangs always in the air . But here , just at [the foot of [these mountains]121-these mountains]1362-the foot of these mountains , there is one little seam of coal , as if placed for the express use of [these people]1364-these people , living so far away from [the larger coal - fields]1365-the larger coal - fields . [The Botfield lime and coal works]1366-the botfield lime and coal works cover only a few acres of the surface ; but underground there are [long passages bored beneath [the pleasant pastures]1368-the pleasant pastures and [the yellow cornfields]1369-the yellow cornfields]1367-long passages bored beneath the pleasant pastures and the yellow cornfields . From [the mountains]74-the mountains , [Botfield]23-botfield looks rather like a great blot upon the fair landscape , with [[its]23-botfield blackened engine - house]1371-its blackened engine - house and banks of coal - dust , [its]23-botfield long range of limekilns , sultry and quivering in the summer sunshine , and [its]23-botfield heavy , groaning water - wheel , which pumps up the water from the pits below . But [the colliers]1372-the colliers do not think it so , nor [[their]1372-the colliers wives]1373-their wives in [the scattered village]1374-the scattered village beyond ; [they]1372-the colliers do not consider the lime and coal works a blot , for [their]1372-the colliers living depends upon [them]1372-the colliers , and [they]1372-the colliers may rightly say , '[129-the husband] As for [the earth]130-the earth , out of it cometh bread : and under it is turned up as it were fire . ' Even [Stephen Fern]19-stephen , who would a thousand times rather work out on [the free hillside]1375-the free hillside than in [the dark passages underground]1376-the dark passages underground , does not think it a pity that the Botfield pit has been discovered at [the foot of [the mountains]74-the mountains]1377-the foot of the mountains . It is nearly seven o'clock in the evening , and [he]19-stephen is coming over [the brow of [the green dell]1380-the green dell]1379-the brow of the green dell , with [his]19-stephen long shadow stretching down it . A very long shadow it is for [so small a figure to cast]1381-so small a figure to cast , for if [we]1382-we wait a minute or two till [Stephen]19-stephen draws nearer , [we]1382-we shall see that [he]19-stephen is [no strong , large man]1383-no strong , large man , but [a slight , thin , stooping boy , bending rather wearily under a sack of coals]1384-a slight , thin , stooping boy , bending rather wearily under a sack of coals , which [he]19-stephen is carrying on [his]19-stephen shoulders , and pausing now and then to wipe [his]19-stephen heated forehead with the sleeve of [his]19-stephen collier 's flannel jacket . When [he]19-stephen lifts up the latch of [[his]19-stephen home]1385-his home [we]1382-we will enter with [him]19-stephen , and see the inside of [the hut]1337-the hut at [[Fern]19-stephen 's Hollow]1387-fern 's hollow . [Stephen]19-stephen stepped over the threshold into [a low , dark room , which was filled with smoke]1388-a low , dark room , which was filled with smoke , from a sudden gust of the wind as it swept over the roof of [the hut]1337-the hut . On one side of the grate , which was made of some half - hoops of iron fastened into the rock , there was [a very aged man , childish and blind with years]1390-a very aged man , childish and blind with years , who was crouching towards the fire , and talking and chuckling to [himself]1390-a very aged man , childish and blind with years . [A girl]1391-a girl , about a year older than [Stephen]19-stephen , sat in a rocking - chair , and swung to and fro as [she]1391-a girl knitted away fast and diligently at a thick grey stocking . In the corner nearest to the fireplace there stood a pallet - bed , hardly raised above the earthen floor , to which [Stephen]19-stephen hastened immediately , with an anxious look at the thin , white face of [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father lying upon the pillow . Beside [the sick man]1393-the sick man there lay [a little child]1394-a little child fast asleep , with [her]1394-a little child hand clasping one of [[her]1394-a little child father]1395-her father 's fingers ; and though [James Fern]20-james fern was shaking and trembling with a violent fit of coughing from the sudden gust of smoke , [he]0-i took care not to loose the hold of those tiny fingers . '[21-miss anne] [Poor little Nan]21-miss anne ! ' [he]0-i whispered to [Stephen]19-stephen , as soon as [he]19-stephen could speak . '[21-miss anne] [I]0-i 've been thinking all day of [her]21-miss anne and [thee]21-miss anne , [lad]131-lad , till [I]0-i 'm nigh heart - broken . '[21-miss anne] ' Do [you]0-i feel worse , [father]1396-father ? '[19-stephen] asked [Stephen]19-stephen anxiously . ' [I]19-stephen 'm[19-stephen] drawing nearer the end , ' answered [James Fern,—'nearer]20-james fern the end every hour ; and [I]19-stephen do n't know for certain what the end will be . [I]19-stephen 'm[19-stephen] repenting ; but [I]0-i ca n't undo the mischief [I]0-i 've done ; [I]0-i must leave that behind [me]0-i . If [I]0-i 'd been anything like [a decent father]132-a decent father , [I]0-i should have left [you]21-miss anne comfortable , instead of [poor beggars]133-poor beggars . And what is to become of [[my]0-i poor lass]134-my poor lass here ? See how fast [she]134-my poor lass clips [my]0-i hand , as if [she]134-my poor lass was afeared [I]0-i was going to leave [her]134-my poor lass ! Oh , [Stephen]19-stephen , [[my]0-i lad]135-my lad , what will [you]21-miss anne all do ? ' '[1396-father] [Father]1396-father , ' said [Stephen]19-stephen , in a quiet and firm voice , '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm getting six shillings a week wages , and [we]21-miss anne can live on very little . [We]21-miss anne have n't got any rent to pay , and only [ourselves]21-miss anne and [grandfather]1397-grandfather to keep , and [Martha]22-martha is as good as [a woman]1398-a woman grown . [We]21-miss anne 'll manage , [father]1396-father , and take care of [little Nan]21-miss anne . '[1396-father] ' [Stephen]19-stephen and [I]22-martha are not bad , [father]1396-father , '[22-martha] added [Martha]22-martha , speaking up proudly ; ' [I]22-martha am not like [Black Bess of Botfield]23-botfield . [Mother]24-mother always told [me]22-martha [I]22-martha was to do [my]22-martha duty ; and [I]22-martha always do it . [I]22-martha can wash , and sew , and iron , and bake , and knit . Why , often and often [we]21-miss anne 've had no more than [Stephen]19-stephen 's earnings , when [you]19-stephen 've been to [the Red Lion]25-the red lion on reckoning nights . '[22-martha] ' Hush , hush , [Martha]22-martha ! '[19-stephen] whispered [Stephen]19-stephen . ' No , it 's true , '[137-the dying father] groaned [the dying father]137-the dying father ; ' [God Almighty]26-god , have mercy on [me]137-the dying father ! [Stephen]19-stephen , hearken to [me]137-the dying father , and [thee]22-martha too , [Martha]22-martha , while [I]137-the dying father tell [you]22-martha about [this place]1401-this place , and what [you]22-martha are to do when [I]137-the dying father 'm[137-the dying father] gone . ' [He]137-the dying father paused for a minute or two , looking earnestly at [the crouching old man in the chimney - corner]1402-the crouching old man in the chimney - corner . '[137-the dying father] [Grandfather]27-grandfather 's quite simple , ' [he]137-the dying father said , '[27-grandfather] and [he]27-grandfather 's dark , too , and does n't know what [any one]138-any one is saying . But [I]0-i know [thee'lt]139-thee'lt be good to [him]27-grandfather , [Stephen]19-stephen . Hearken , [children]1322-children : [[your]19-stephen poor old grandfather]141-your poor old grandfather was once in [jail]142-jail , and was sent across [the seas]143-the seas , for [a thief]144-a thief . ' '[28-father] [Father]28-father ! ' cried [Stephen]19-stephen , in a tone of deep distress ; and [he]19-stephen turned quickly to [the old man]1403-the old man , remembering how often [he]19-stephen had sat upon [his]19-stephen knees by the winter fire , and how many summer days [he]19-stephen had rambled with [him]19-stephen over [the uplands]93-the uplands after the sheep . [[His]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather had been far kinder to [him]19-stephen than [[his]19-stephen own father]1406-his own father ; and [his]19-stephen heart swelled with anger as [he]19-stephen went and laid [his]19-stephen arm round the bending neck of [the old man]1403-the old man , who looked up in [his]19-stephen face and laughed heartily . '[28-father] Come back , [Stephen]19-stephen ; it 's true , ' gasped [James Fern]20-james fern . '[19-stephen] [Poor mother]145-poor mother and [me]0-i came [here]146-here , where [nobody]147-nobody knew [us]148-us , while [he]149-he was away for more than twenty years ; and [she]145-poor mother built a hut for - [us]148-us to live in till [he]149-he came back . [I]0-i was [a little lad]150-a little lad then , but as soon as [I]0-i was big enough [she]145-poor mother made [me]0-i learn to read and write , that [I]0-i might send letters to [him]149-he beyond [the seas]143-the seas and [none of [the neighbours]153-the neighbours]152-none of the neighbours know . [She]145-poor mother 'd often make [me]0-i read to [her]145-poor mother about [a poor fellow who had left [home]125-home and gone to [a far country]156-a far country]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country , and when [he]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country came [home]125-home again , how [[his]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country father]1392-his father saw [him]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country a long way off . Well , [she]145-poor mother was just like that when [she]145-poor mother 'd heard that [he]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country was landed in [England]4-england ; [she]145-poor mother did nought but sit over [the bent of [the hill yonder]160-the hill yonder]159-the bent of the hill yonder , peering along [the road to [Botfield]23-botfield]161-the road to botfield ; and one evening at sundown [she]145-poor mother saw something , little more than a speck upon the turf , and [she]145-poor mother 'd a feeling come over [her]145-poor mother that it was [he]154-a poor fellow who had left home and gone to a far country , and [she]145-poor mother fainted for real joy . After all , [we]162-we were n't much happier when [we]162-we were settled down like . [Grandfather]27-grandfather had learned to tend sheep out yonder , and [I]0-i worked at [Botfield]23-botfield ; but [we]162-we never laid by money to build [a brick house]163-a brick house , as [poor mother]145-poor mother always wanted [us]162-we . [She]145-poor mother died a month or so afore [I]0-i was married to [[your]165-your mother]166-your mother . ' [James Fern]20-james fern was silent again for some minutes , leaning back upon [his]20-james fern pillow , with [his]20-james fern eyes closed , and [his]20-james fern thoughts gone back to the old times . '[145-poor mother] If [I]0-i 'd only been like [mother]167-mother , [you]165-your 'd have been [a hill - farmer]168-a hill - farmer now , [Steve]19-stephen , ' [he]0-i continued , in a tone of regret ; '[145-poor mother] [she]145-poor mother plotted out in [her]145-poor mother own mind to take in [the green before [us]162-we]169-the green before us , for rearing young lambs , and ducks , and goslings . But [I]0-i was like [that poor lad that wasted all [his]170-that poor lad that wasted all his substance in riotous living substance in riotous living]170-that poor lad that wasted all his substance in riotous living ; and [I]0-i 've let [thee]171-thee and [[thy]171-thee sister]172-thy sister grow up without even the learning [I]0-i could have given [thee]171-thee ; and learning is light carriage . But , [lad]131-lad , remember [this house]174-this house is [thy]171-thee own , and never part with it ; never give it up , for it is [thy]171-thee right . Maybe [they]175-they 'll want to turn [thee]171-thee out , because [thee]171-thee art [a boy]176-a boy ; but [I]0-i 've lived in [it]174-this house nigh upon forty years , and [I]0-i 've written it all down upon this piece of paper , and that [the place]177-the place is thine , [Stephen]19-stephen . ' '[19-stephen] [I]0-i 'll never give it up , [father]1396-father , ' said [Stephen]19-stephen , in [his]0-i steady voice . '[19-stephen] [Stephen]19-stephen , ' continued [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father , '[19-stephen] [the master]179-the master has set [his]179-the master heart upon it to make it [a hill - farm]180-a hill - farm ; and [thou'lt]181-thy have hard work to hold [thy]181-thy own against [him]179-the master . [Thou]181-thy must frame [thy]181-thy words well when [he]179-the master speaks to [thee]181-thy about it , for [he]179-the master 's [a cunning man]182-a cunning man . And there 's another paper , which [the parson at [Danesford]5-danesford]183-the parson at danesford has in [his]183-the parson at danesford keeping , to certify that [mother]167-mother built [this house]174-this house and dwelt in [it]174-this house all the days of [her]167-mother life , more than thirty years ; if there 's any mischief worked against [thee]181-thy , go to [him]183-the parson at danesford for it . And now , [Stephen]19-stephen , wash [thyself]186-thyself , and get [thy]181-thy supper , and then let ['s]187-'s hear [thee]181-thy read [thy]181-thy chapter . ' [Stephen]19-stephen carried [his]19-stephen basin of potatoes to the door - sill and sat there , with [his]19-stephen back turned to [the dismal hut]1409-the dismal hut and [[his]19-stephen dying father]1410-his dying father , and [his]19-stephen face looking out upon [the green hills]1411-the green hills . [He]19-stephen had always been [a grave and thoughtful boy]1412-a grave and thoughtful boy ; and [he]19-stephen had much to think of now . The deep sense of new duties and obligations that had come upon [him]19-stephen with [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father 's words , made [him]19-stephen feel that [[his]19-stephen boyhood]1414-his boyhood had passed away . [He]19-stephen looked round upon [the garden]1350-the garden , and [the field]1416-the field , and [the hut]1337-the hut , with the keen eye of [an owner]1418-an owner ; and [he]19-stephen wondered at the neglected state into which they had fallen since [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father 's illness . There could be no more play - time for [him]19-stephen ; no bird's - nesting among the gorse - bushes ; no rabbit - bunting with [Snip]29-snip , the little white terrier that was sharing [his]19-stephen supper . If [little Nan]21-miss anne and [[his]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather were to be provided for , [he]188-his must be [a man]1421-a man , with [a man]1421-a man 's thoughtfulness , doing [man]1423-man 's work . There seemed enough work for [him]188-his to do in [the field]1416-the field and [garden]1425-garden alone , without [his]188-his twelve hours '[181-thy] toil in the coal - pit ; but [his]188-his weekly wages would now be more necessary than ever . [He]188-his must get up early , and go to bed late , and labour without a moment 's rest , doing [his]188-his utmost from one day to another , with [no one]189-no one to help [him]188-his , or stand for a little while in [his]188-his place . For a few minutes [his]188-his brave spirit sank within [him]188-his , and all the landscape swam before [his]188-his eyes ; while [Snip]29-snip took advantage of [[his]29-snip master]190-his master 's inattention to put [his]29-snip nose into the basin , and help [himself]29-snip to the largest share of the potatoes . ' [I]22-martha mean to be like [grandmother]1426-grandmother , '[22-martha] said [Martha]22-martha 's clear , sharp voice , close beside [him]188-his , and [he]188-his saw [[his]188-his sister]191-his sister looking eagerly round [her]22-martha . ' [I]22-martha shall fence [the green]1427-the green in , and have lambs and sheep to turn out on [the hillside]1428-the hillside , and [I]22-martha 'll rear young goslings and ducks for market ; and [we]1429-we 'll have [a brick house]163-a brick house , with two rooms in [it]163-a brick house , as well as a shed for the coal . And [nobody]147-nobody shall put upon [us]1429-we , or touch [our]1429-we rights , [Stephen]19-stephen , or [they]147-nobody shall have the length of [my]22-martha tongue . '[22-martha] ' [Martha]22-martha , '[19-stephen] said [Stephen]19-stephen earnestly , ' do [you]22-martha see how a shower is raining down on [[the master]179-the master 's fields at [Botfield]23-botfield]1433-the master 's fields at botfield ; and [they]1433-the master 's fields at botfield 've been scorched up for want of water ? '[19-stephen] ' Yes , surely , '[22-martha] answered [Martha]22-martha ; ' and what of that ? '[22-martha] ' [I]19-stephen 'm[19-stephen] thinking , ' continued [Stephen]19-stephen , rather shyly , '[19-stephen] of that verse in [my]0-i chapter : " [He]19-stephen maketh the sun to rise on the evil and the good , and sendeth rain on the just and the unjust . " What sort of [a man]1421-a man is [the master]179-the master , [Martha]22-martha ? ' '[22-martha] [He]19-stephen 's [a bad , unjust , niggardly old miser]194-a bad , unjust , niggardly old miser , ' replied [Martha]22-martha . '[19-stephen] And if [God]26-god sends [him]19-stephen rain , and takes care of [him]19-stephen , ' [Stephen]19-stephen said , '[26-god] how much more care will [He]19-stephen take of [us]195-us , if [we]195-us are good , and try to do [His]19-stephen commandments ! ' '[0-i] [I]0-i should think , ' said [Martha]22-martha , but in a softer tone , '[0-i] [I]0-i should really think [He]19-stephen would give [us]195-us the green , and the lambs , and [the new house]196-the new house , and everything ; for both of [us]195-us are good , [Stephen]19-stephen . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know , ' replied [Stephen]19-stephen ; '[0-i] if [I]0-i could read all the Bible , perhaps it would tell [us]195-us . But now [I]0-i must go in and read [my]0-i chapter to [father]1396-father . ' [Martha]22-martha went back to [her]22-martha rocking - chair and knitting , while [Stephen]19-stephen reached down from a shelf an old Bible , covered with green baize , and , having carefully looked that [his]19-stephen hard hands were quite clean , [he]19-stephen opened it with the greatest reverence . [James Fern]20-james fern had only begun to teach [the boy]1434-the boy to read a few months before , when [he]20-james fern felt the first fatal symptoms of [his]20-james fern illness ; and [Stephen]19-stephen , with [his]19-stephen few opportunities for learning , had only mastered one chapter , the fifth chapter of [St. Matthew]30-st. matthew 's Gospel , which [[his]1434-the boy father]1392-his father had chosen for [him]1434-the boy to begin with . [The sick man]1393-the sick man lay still with closed eyes , but listening attentively to every word , and correcting [[his]1393-the sick man son]1312-his son whenever [he]1393-the sick man made any mistake . When it was finished , [James Fern]20-james fern read a few verses aloud [himself]20-james fern , with low voice and frequent pauses to regain [his]20-james fern strength ; and very soon afterwards [the whole family]1438-the whole family were in a deep sleep , except [himself]20-james fern . [James Fern]20-james fern did not live many more days , and [he]20-james fern was buried the Sunday following [his]20-james fern death . [All the colliers]1439-all the colliers and [pitmen from [Botfield]23-botfield]1440-pitmen from botfield walked with the funeral of [[their]1439-all the colliers old comrade]1441-their old comrade and made a great burial of it . [The parish church]1442-the parish church was two miles on [the other side of [Botfield]23-botfield]1443-the other side of botfield , and four miles from [[Fern]20-james fern 's Hollow]1387-fern 's hollow ; so [James Fern]20-james fern and [[his]20-james fern family]1445-his family had never , as [he]20-james fern called it , '[0-i] troubled ' [the church]1446-the church with [their]1438-the whole family attendance . [All the household]1447-all the household , even to [little Nan]21-miss anne , went with [[their]1447-all the household father]1448-their father 's corpse , to bury [it]1441-their old comrade in [the strange and distant churchyard]1449-the strange and distant churchyard . [Stephen]19-stephen felt as if [he]19-stephen was in some long and painful dream , as [he]19-stephen sat in [the cart]1450-the cart , with [his]19-stephen feet resting upon [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father 's coffin , with [[his]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather on a chair at the head , nodding and laughing at every jolt on [the rough road]1453-the rough road , and [Martha]22-martha holding a handkerchief up to [her]22-martha face , and carrying a large umbrella over [herself]22-martha and [little Nan]21-miss anne , to keep the dust off [their]1447-all the household new black bonnets . [The boy]1434-the boy , grave as [he]1434-the boy was , could hardly think ; [he]1434-the boy felt in too great a maze for that . [The church]1446-the church , too , which [he]1434-the boy had never entered before , seemed grand and cold and immense , with [its]1446-the church lofty arches , and a roof so high that it made [him]1434-the boy giddy to look up to [it]1446-the church . Now and then [he]1434-the boy heard a few sentences of the burial service sounding out grandly in [the clergyman]1456-the clergyman 's strange , deep voice ; but they were not words [he]1434-the boy was familiar with , and [he]1434-the boy could not understand their meaning . At [the open grave]1457-the open grave only , [the clergyman]1456-the clergyman said '[199-our father] [[Our]198-our Father]199-our father , ' which [[his]1434-the boy father]1392-his father had taught [him]1434-the boy during [his]1392-his father illness ; and while [his]1434-the boy tears rolled down [his]1434-the boy cheeks for the first time that day , [Stephen]19-stephen repeated over and over again to [himself]19-stephen , '[199-our father] [[Our]198-our Father]199-our father ! [[our]198-our Father]199-our father ! ' [Stephen]19-stephen would have liked to stay in [the church]1446-the church for the evening service , for which the bells were already ringing ; but this did not at all suit the tastes of [[his]19-stephen father 's old comrades]1461-his father 's old comrades . [They]1461-his father 's old comrades made haste to crowd into [a public - house]1462-a public - house , where [they]1461-his father 's old comrades sat and drank , and forced [Stephen]19-stephen to drink too , in order to '[0-i] drown [his]199-our father grief . ' It was still a painful dream to [him]19-stephen ; and more and more , as the long hours passed on , [he]19-stephen wondered how [he]19-stephen came [there]1463-there , and what [all the people]1464-all the people about [him]19-stephen were doing . It was quite dark before [they]1461-his father 's old comrades started homewards , and [the poor old grandfather]1465-the poor old grandfather was no longer able to sit up in [his]1465-the poor old grandfather chair , but lay helplessly at the bottom of [the cart]1450-the cart . Even [Martha]22-martha was fast asleep , and leaned [her]22-martha head upon [Stephen]19-stephen 's shoulder , without any regard for [her]22-martha new black bonnet . [The cart]1450-the cart was now crowded with as many of [the people]1468-the people as could get into it , who sang and shouted along [the quiet Sunday road]1469-the quiet sunday road ; and , as [they]1461-his father 's old comrades insisted upon stopping at [every public - house]1470-every public - house [they]1461-his father 's old comrades came to , it was very late before [they]1461-his father 's old comrades reached [the lane leading up to [Fern]19-stephen 's Hollow]1471-the lane leading up to fern 's hollow . [The grandfather]1472-the grandfather was half dragged and half carried along by [two of [the men]1474-the men]1473-two of the men , followed by [Stephen]19-stephen bearing [sleepy little Nan]21-miss anne in [his]19-stephen arms , and by [Martha]22-martha , who had wakened up in a temper between crying and scolding . The long , strange , painful dream of [father]1396-father 's funeral was not over yet , and [Stephen]19-stephen was still trying to think in a stupid , drowsy fashion , when [he]19-stephen fell heavily asleep on the bed beside [[his]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather . [He]19-stephen awoke by habit very early in the morning , and aroused [himself]19-stephen with a great effort against dropping asleep again . [He]19-stephen could realize and understand [his]19-stephen position better now . [Father]28-father was dead ; and there was [no one]189-no one to earn bread for [them]1474-the men all but [himself]19-stephen . At this thought [he]19-stephen sprang up instantly , though [his]19-stephen head was aching in a manner [he]19-stephen had never felt before . With some difficulty [he]19-stephen awoke [Martha]22-martha to get [his]19-stephen breakfast and put up [his]19-stephen dinner in a basket which [he]19-stephen carried with [him]19-stephen to [the pit]1478-the pit . [She]22-martha also complained bitterly of [her]22-martha head aching , and moved about with a listlessness very different to [her]22-martha usual activity . '[0-i] [I]0-i only wish [I]0-i knew what was right , ' said [Stephen]19-stephen to [himself]0-i ; '[202-they] [they]202-they told [us]203-us [we]203-us ought to show respect for [father]1396-father , but [I]0-i do n't think [he]1396-father 'd like this . Perhaps if [I]0-i could read the Bible all through , that would tell [me]0-i everything . ' This thought reminded [Stephen]19-stephen that [he]19-stephen had promised [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father to read [his]19-stephen chapter every day of [his]19-stephen life till [he]19-stephen knew how to read more ; and , carrying the old Bible to [his]19-stephen favourite seat on the door - sill , a very pleasant place in the cool , fresh summer morning , [he]19-stephen read the verses aloud , slowly and carefully , rather repeating than reading them , for [he]19-stephen knew [his]19-stephen chapter better by heart than by the printed letters in the book . Thank [God]26-god , [Stephen Fern]19-stephen did begin to know it by heart ! It was not a bad day in [the pit]1478-the pit . [All the colliers]1439-all the colliers , [men]1482-men and [boys]1326-boys , were more gentle than usual with [the fatherless lad]1484-the fatherless lad ; and even [Black Thompson]31-black thompson , [[his]19-stephen master]190-his master since [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father 's illness , who was in general [a fierce bully to everybody about [him]31-black thompson]1487-a fierce bully to everybody about him , spoke as mildly as [he]31-black thompson could to [Stephen]19-stephen . Yet all the day [Stephen]19-stephen longed for [his]19-stephen release in the evening , thinking how much work there wanted doing in [the garden]1350-the garden , and how [he]19-stephen and [Martha]22-martha must be busy in it till nightfall . The clanking of the chain which drew [him]19-stephen up to the light of day sounded like music to [him]19-stephen ; but little did [he]19-stephen guess that [an enemy]1489-an enemy was lying in wait for [him]19-stephen at [the mouth of [the pit]1478-the pit]1490-the mouth of the pit . '[32-hillo] [Hillo]32-hillo ! ' cried a voice down [the shaft]1492-the shaft as [they]32-hillo were nearing the top ; '[32-hillo] [one of [you]32-hillo chaps]205-one of you chaps have got to carry a sack o ' coals one mile . '[32-hillo] The voice belonged to [Tim Cole]33-tim , who was the terror of [the pit - bank]206-the pit - bank , from [his]33-tim love of mischief and [his]33-tim insatiable desire for fighting . [He]33-tim was looking down [the shaft]1492-the shaft now , with a grin and a laugh upon [his]33-tim red face , round which [his]33-tim shaggy red hair hung like a rough mane . There were only [two other boys besides [Stephen]19-stephen in the skip]208-two other boys besides stephen in the skip , and as [[their]208-two other boys besides stephen in the skip fathers]209-their fathers were with [them]208-two other boys besides stephen in the skip it might be dangerous to meddle with [them]208-two other boys besides stephen in the skip ; so [Tim]33-tim fixed upon [Stephen]19-stephen as [his]33-tim prey . ' [Thee]19-stephen has got to carry these coals , [Steve]19-stephen , '[33-tim] [he]33-tim said , [his]33-tim eyes dancing with delight . ' [I]19-stephen wo n't , '[19-stephen] replied [Stephen]19-stephen . ' [Thee]19-stephen shalt , '[33-tim] cried [Tim]33-tim , with an oath . ' [I]19-stephen wo n't , '[19-stephen] [Stephen]19-stephen repeated stedfastly . ' Then [we]1493-we 'll fight for it , '[33-tim] said [Tim]33-tim , clenching [his]33-tim fists and squaring [his]33-tim arms , while [the men]1474-the men and [boys]1326-boys formed a ring round [the two lads]212-the two lads , and [one and another]213-one and another spoke encouragingly to [Stephen]19-stephen , who was somewhat slighter and younger than [Tim]33-tim . [He]19-stephen had beaten [Tim]33-tim once before , but that was months ago ; yet the blood rushed into [Stephen]19-stephen 's face , and [he]19-stephen set [his]19-stephen lips together firmly . Up yonder , just within the range of [his]19-stephen sight , was [[Fern]19-stephen 's Hollow]1387-fern 's hollow , with [[its]1387-fern 's hollow neglected garden]215-its neglected garden , and [his]19-stephen supper waiting for [him]19-stephen ; and here was the heavy sack of coals to be carried for a mile , or the choice of fighting with [Tim]33-tim . ' [I]19-stephen wish [I]19-stephen knew what [I]19-stephen ought to do , '[19-stephen] [he]19-stephen said , speaking aloud , though speaking to [himself]19-stephen . ' Ay , ay , [lad]131-lad , '[31-black thompson] cried [Black Thompson]31-black thompson ; ' it 's a shame to make [thee]131-lad fight , and [[thy]131-lad father]1495-thy father not cold in [the graveyard]1496-the graveyard yet . [I]31-black thompson say , [Tim]33-tim , what is it [thee]131-lad wants ? '[31-black thompson] ' These coals , '[33-tim] answered [Tim]33-tim doggedly , ' are to be carried to [the New Farm]1497-the new farm ; and if [Stevie Fern]19-stephen wo n't take them one mile , [he]19-stephen must fight [me]33-tim afore [he]19-stephen goes off [this bank]1498-this bank . '[33-tim] ' Now , [lads]1499-lads , [I]31-black thompson 'll judge between [ye]1499-lads this time , '[31-black thompson] said [Black Thompson]31-black thompson . ' [Stevie]19-stephen shall carry [them]1500-them to [the end of [Red Lane]6-red lane]1501-the end of red lane , and cut across the hill home : that 's not much out of the way ; and if [Tim]33-tim makes [him]33-tim go one step farther , [I]31-black thompson 'll lick [thee]1499-lads [myself]31-black thompson to - morrow , [lad]131-lad , [I]31-black thompson promise [thee]1499-lads . '[31-black thompson] [Stephen]19-stephen hoisted the sack upon [his]19-stephen shoulders in silence , and strode away with a swelling heart , in which a tumult of anger and perplexity was raging . ' If [I]19-stephen had only a commandment about these things ! '[19-stephen] [he]19-stephen thought . [He]19-stephen was not quite certain whether it would not have been best and wisest to fight with [Tim]33-tim and have it out ; especially as [Tim]33-tim was all the time taunting [him]19-stephen for being [a coward]216-a coward . But [[his]19-stephen father]1392-his father had read much to [him]19-stephen during the last three months ; and though [he]19-stephen could not remember any particular commandment , [he]19-stephen felt sure that the Bible did not encourage fighting or drunkenness . Suddenly , and before [they]218-they reached the end of [Red Lane]6-red lane , a light burst upon [Stephen]19-stephen 's mind . ' [I]19-stephen say , [Tim]33-tim , '[19-stephen] [he]19-stephen said , speaking to [him]33-tim for the first time , ' it 's four miles to [the New Farm]1497-the new farm , and [I]19-stephen 'll go with [thee]33-tim a mile farther than [Red Lane]6-red lane . '[19-stephen] ' Eh ! '[33-tim] cried [Tim]33-tim ; ' and get [Black Thompson]31-black thompson to lick [me]33-tim to - morrow ? '[33-tim] ' No , '[19-stephen] said [Stephen]19-stephen earnestly , ' [I]19-stephen 'll not tell [Black Thompson]31-black thompson ; and if [he]31-black thompson hears talk of it , [I]19-stephen 'll say [I]19-stephen did it of [my]19-stephen own mind . Come [thy]33-tim ways , [Tim]33-tim ; let 's be sharp , for [I]19-stephen 've [my]19-stephen potatoes to hoe when [I]19-stephen get [home]125-home to - night . '[19-stephen] [The boys]219-the boys walked briskly on for a few minutes , past the end of [Red Lane]6-red lane , though [Stephen]19-stephen cast a wistful glance up it , and gave an impatient jerk to the load upon [his]19-stephen shoulders . [Tim]33-tim had been walking beside [him]19-stephen in silent reflection ; but at last [he]33-tim came to a sudden halt . ' [I]33-tim ca n't make it out , '[33-tim] [he]33-tim said . ' What art [thee]33-tim up to , [Stephen]19-stephen ? Tell [me]33-tim out plain , or [I]33-tim 'll fight [thee]33-tim here , if [Black Thompson]31-black thompson does lick [me]33-tim for it . '[33-tim] ' Why , [I]19-stephen 've been learning to read , '[19-stephen] answered [Stephen]19-stephen , with some pride , ' and of course [I]19-stephen know things [I]19-stephen did n't used to know , and what [thee]33-tim does n't know now . '[19-stephen] ' And what 's that to do with it ? '[33-tim] inquired [Tim]33-tim . ' [My]19-stephen chapter says that if [any man]1505-any man forces [me]19-stephen to go one mile , [I]19-stephen am to go two , '[19-stephen] replied [Stephen]19-stephen ; ' it does n't say why exactly , but [I]19-stephen 'm[19-stephen] going to try what good it will be to [me]0-i to do everything that [my]0-i book tells [me]0-i . ' '[19-stephen] It 's a queer book , ' said [Tim]33-tim , after a pause . '[19-stephen] Does it say [a chap]220-a chap may make [another chap]221-another chap do [his]221-another chap work for [him]221-another chap ? ' '[221-another chap] No , ' [Stephen]19-stephen answered ; '[221-another chap] but it says [we]222-we are to love [[our]222-we enemies]223-our enemies , and do good to [them]223-our enemies that hate [us]222-we , that [we]222-we may be [the children of [[our]222-we Father]199-our father which is in [heaven]226-heaven]224-the children of our father which is in heaven — that is [God]26-god , [Tim]33-tim . So that is why [I]0-i am going a mile farther with [thee]33-tim . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't hate [thee]33-tim , ' said [Tim]33-tim uneasily , '[0-i] but [I]0-i do love fighting ; [I]0-i 'd liever thee'd fight than come another mile . Do n't [thee]33-tim come any farther , [I]0-i 've been bone lazy all day , and [thee]33-tim 's been at work . And [I]0-i say , [Stevie]19-stephen , [I]0-i 'll help [thee]33-tim with the potatoes to - morrow , to make up for this bout . ' [Stephen]19-stephen thanked [him]33-tim , and accepted [his]33-tim offer heartily . The load was quickly transferred to [Tim]33-tim 's broad back , and [the boys]219-the boys parted in more good - will than [they]219-the boys had ever felt before ; [Stephen]19-stephen strengthened by this favourable result in [his]19-stephen resolution to put in practice all [he]19-stephen knew of the Bible ; and [Tim]33-tim deep in thought , as was evident from [his]33-tim muttering every now and then on [his]33-tim way to [the New Farm]1497-the new farm , '[0-i] Queer book that ; and [a queer chap]227-a queer chap too ! ' [Little Nan]34-little nan would be waiting for [him]19-stephen , as well as [his]19-stephen supper , and [Stephen]19-stephen forgot [his]19-stephen weariness as [he]19-stephen bounded along [the soft turf]1508-the soft turf , to the great discomfiture of the brown - faced sheep , quite as anxious for [their]219-the boys supper as [he]19-stephen was for [his]19-stephen . [Stephen]19-stephen heard far off [Snip]29-snip 's sharp , impatient bark , and it made [him]19-stephen quicken [his]19-stephen steps still more , until , coming within sight of [[his]19-stephen own Hollow]1509-his own hollow , [he]19-stephen stopped suddenly , and [his]19-stephen heart beat even more vehemently than when [he]19-stephen was running up [the hillside]1428-the hillside . There was , however , nothing very terrible in the scene . [The hut]1337-the hut was safe , and the sun was shining brightly upon [the garden]1350-the garden , and [little Nan]34-little nan was standing as usual at the wicket . Only in the [oat - field]1513-oat - field , with [their]219-the boys faces looking across the green , stood [two men in close conversation]1514-two men in close conversation . [These men]1515-these men were both of [them]1515-these men old , and rather thin and shrivelled in figure ; [their]1515-these men features bore great resemblance to each other , the eyes being small and sunken , with many wrinkles round [them]1515-these men , and both mouths much fallen in . [You]1516-you would have said at once [they]1515-these men were [brothers]1517-brothers ; and if [you]1516-you drew near enough to hear [their]1515-these men conversation , [you]1516-you would have found [your]1516-you guess was right . '[35-brother thomas] [Brother Thomas]35-brother thomas , ' said [the thinnest and sharpest - looking]1518-the thinnest and sharpest - looking , '[35-brother thomas] [I]0-i intend to enclose as far as [we]228-we can see from this point . [That southern bank]229-that southern bank will be [a first - rate place for [young animals]231-young animals]230-a first - rate place for young animals . [I]0-i shall build [a house]232-a house , with [three rooms above and below]233-three rooms above and below , besides [a small dairy]234-a small dairy ; and [I]0-i shall plant a fir - wood behind [it]232-a house to keep off the east winds . The lime and bricks from [[my]0-i own works]235-my own works will not cost [me]0-i much more than the expense of bringing them up [here]146-here . ' '[238-you] And [a very pretty little hill - farm]237-a very pretty little hill - farm [you]238-you 'll make of [it]237-a very pretty little hill - farm , [James]20-james fern , ' replied [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley admiringly . '[20-james fern] [I]0-i should not wonder now if [you]238-you got £ 20 a year rent for it . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i shall get £ 25 in a few years , ' said [the other one]1519-the other one : '[0-i] just think of the run for ponies on [the hill]1336-the hill , to say nothing of sheep . [A young , hard - working man]240-a young , hard - working man could make a very tidy living up [here]146-here ; and [we]242-we shall have [a respectable house]243-a respectable house , instead of [[a pauper]244-a pauper 's family]245-a pauper 's family . ' '[244-a pauper] It will be a benefit to [the neighbourhood]246-the neighbourhood , ' observed [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley . [The latter speaker]1520-the latter speaker , who was a degree pleasanter - looking than [[his]1520-the latter speaker brother]1521-his brother , was [the relieving officer of [the large union to which [Botfield]23-botfield belonged]1523-the large union to which botfield belonged]1522-the relieving officer of the large union to which botfield belonged ; and , in consequence , [all poor persons who had grown too old , or were in any way unable to work]1524-all poor persons who had grown too old , or were in any way unable to work , were compelled to apply to [him]1520-the latter speaker for the help which the laws of [[our]242-we country]1525-our country provide for such cases . [James Wyley]37-james wyley , [the elder brother]1526-the elder brother , was [the owner of [Botfield works]1528-botfield works]1527-the owner of botfield works , and [the master of all [the people employed in them]1530-the people employed in them , besides being [the agent of [the lord of the manor]94-the lord of the manor]1531-the agent of the lord of the manor]1529-the master of all the people employed in them , besides being the agent of the lord of the manor . So both [these men]1515-these men possessed great authority over [the poor]1534-the poor ; and [they]1515-these men used the power to oppress [them]1534-the poor and grind [them]1534-the poor down to the utmost . It was therefore no wonder that [Stephen]19-stephen stopped instantly when [he]19-stephen saw [their]1515-these men well - known figures standing at the corner of [[his]19-stephen oat - field]1535-his oat - field ; nor that [he]19-stephen should come on slowly after [he]19-stephen had recovered [his]19-stephen courage , pondering in [his]19-stephen own mind what [they]1515-these men were come up to [Fern 's Hollow]2-fern 's hollow for , and how [he]19-stephen should answer [them]1515-these men if [they]1515-these men should want [him]19-stephen to give up [the old hut]1536-the old hut . '[244-a pauper] Good evening , [[my]0-i lad]135-my lad , ' said [James Wyley]37-james wyley , smiling a slow , reluctant smile , as [Stephen]19-stephen drew near to [them]1515-these men with [his]19-stephen cap in [his]19-stephen hand . '[244-a pauper] So [you]135-my lad buried [[your]135-my lad father]248-your father yesterday , [I]0-i hear . [Poor fellow]249-poor fellow ! there was not a better collier at [Botfield]23-botfield than [James Fern]20-james fern . ' '[20-james fern] Never troubled [[his]248-your father parish]250-his parish for a sixpence , ' added [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley . '[20-james fern] Thank [you]0-i , [master]251-master , ' said [Stephen]19-stephen , the tears starting to [his]19-stephen eyes , so unexpected was this gentle greeting to [him]19-stephen ; '[251-master] [I]0-i 'll try to be like [father]1396-father . ' '[0-i] Well , [[my]0-i boy]253-my boy , ' said [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley , '[0-i] [we]254-we are come up here on purpose to give [you]253-my boy [our]254-we advice , as [you]253-my boy are such [a mere lad]255-a mere lad . [I]0-i 've been thinking what can be done for [you]253-my boy . There 's [[your]253-my boy grandfather]256-your grandfather , [a poor , simple , helpless old man]257-a poor , simple , helpless old man , and [the little girl]258-the little girl — why , of course [we]254-we shall have to receive [them]259-them into [the House]1347-the house ; and [I]0-i 'll see there is no difficulty made about it . Then [we]254-we intend to get [[your]253-my boy sister]261-your sister into some right good service . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i should not mind taking [her]261-your sister into [[my]0-i own house]262-my own house , ' said [the master]179-the master , [Mr. James Wyley]37-james wyley ; '[0-i] [she]261-your sister would soon learn under [[my]0-i niece]263-my niece [Anne]34-little nan . So [you]253-my boy will be set free to get [your]253-my boy own living without encumbrance ; [you]253-my boy are earning [your]253-my boy six shillings now , and that will keep [you]253-my boy well . ' '[264-sir] Please , [sir]264-sir , ' answered [Stephen]19-stephen , '[264-sir] [we]254-we mean to live all together as [we]254-we 've been used ; and [I]0-i could n't let [grandfather]1397-grandfather and [little Nan]34-little nan come upon [the parish]266-the parish . [Martha]22-martha must stay at [home]125-home to mind [them]268-them ; and [I]0-i 'll work [my]0-i fingers to the bone for [them]268-them all , [sir]264-sir . [Many]270-many thanks all the same to [you]264-sir for coming up here to see after [us]254-we . ' '[264-sir] Very fine indeed , [my little fellow]271-my little fellow , ' said [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley ; '[264-sir] but [you]271-my little fellow do n't understand what [you]271-my little fellow are talking about . It is [my]0-i place to see after [the poor]1534-the poor , and [I]0-i can not leave [you]271-my little fellow in charge of such [a very old man]273-a very old man and [such a child as this]274-such a child as this , No , no ; [they]268-them must be taken care of ; and [they]268-them 'll be made right comfortable in [the House]1347-the house . ' '[28-father] [Father]28-father said , ' replied [Stephen]19-stephen , '[28-father] that [I]0-i was never to let [grandfather]1397-grandfather and [little Nan]34-little nan come upon [the parish]266-the parish . [I]0-i get [my]0-i wages , and [we]278-we 've no rent to pay ; and the potatoes and oats will help [us]278-we ; and [Martha]22-martha can pick bilberries on [the hill]1336-the hill , and carry bundles of firing to [the village]280-the village ; and [we]278-we 'll do well enough without [the parish]266-the parish . Many thanks all the same to [you]28-father , [sir]264-sir . ' '[283-you] Hark [ye]283-you , [[my]0-i lad]135-my lad , ' said [the master]179-the master impatiently . '[283-you] [I]0-i want to buy [[your]283-you old hut]285-your old hut and [field]286-field from [you]283-you . [I]0-i 'll give [ye]283-you a ten - pound note for it ; a whole ten pounds . Why , a fortune for [you]283-you ! ' '[28-father] [Father]28-father said , ' repeated [Stephen]19-stephen , '[28-father] [I]0-i was never to give up [[Fern]19-stephen 's [Hollow]8-hollow]1387-fern 's hollow ; and [I]0-i gave [him]288-him a sure promise for that , and to take care of [little Nan]34-little nan as long as ever [I]0-i lived . ' '[34-little nan] [[Fern]19-stephen 's [Hollow]8-hollow]1387-fern 's hollow is none of [yours]283-you , ' cried [the master]179-the master , in a rage ; '[283-you] [you]283-you 've just been [a family of [paupers]291-paupers and [squatters]292-squatters]290-a family of paupers and squatters , living up here by poaching and thieving . [I]0-i 'll unearth [you]283-you , [I]0-i promise [ye]283-you ; [you]283-you have been a disgrace to [the manor]293-the manor long enough . So it is ten pounds or nothing for [[your]283-you old hole]294-your old hole ; and [you]283-you may take [your]283-you choice . ' '[264-sir] Please , [sir]264-sir , ' said [Stephen]19-stephen firmly , '[264-sir] [the place]177-the place is [ours]297-ours , and [I]0-i 'm never to part with [it]177-the place . [I]264-sir 'll never poach , and [I]264-sir 'll never trespass on [the manor]293-the manor ; but [I]264-sir ca n't sell [the old house]1541-the old house , [sir]264-sir . '[264-sir] ' Now , just listen to [me]36-mr. wyley , [young Fern]19-stephen , '[36-mr. wyley] said [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley ; ' [you]283-you 'll be compelled to give up [[Fern]19-stephen 's Hollow in right of [the lord of the manor]94-the lord of the manor]1543-fern 's hollow in right of the lord of the manor ; and then if [you]283-you come to [the House]1347-the house for relief , mark [my]36-mr. wyley words , [I]36-mr. wyley 'll send [[your]283-you grandfather]256-your grandfather off to [Bristol]9-bristol , for that 's [[his]256-your grandfather parish]250-his parish , and [you]283-you 'll never see [him]256-your grandfather again ; and [I]36-mr. wyley 'll give orders for [you]283-you never to see [little Nan]34-little nan ; and [I]36-mr. wyley 'll apprentice [you]283-you and [[your]283-you other sister]1548-your other sister in different places . So [you]283-you had better be reasonable , and take [our]1549-our advice while [you]283-you can be made comfortable . '[36-mr. wyley] ' Please , [sir]264-sir , [I]19-stephen ca n't go against [my]19-stephen promise , '[19-stephen] answered [Stephen]19-stephen , with a sob . ' What 's the use of wasting [one]1551-one 's breath ? '[179-the master] said [the master]179-the master ; ' [this place [I]179-the master want]1552-this place i want , and [this place [I]179-the master 'll have]1553-this place i 'll have ; and [we]1549-our 'll see if [this young jail - bird]1554-this young jail - bird will stand in [my]179-the master way . Ah , [[my]179-the master fine fellow]1555-my fine fellow , it 's no such secret where [[your]283-you grandfather]256-your grandfather spent twenty - one years of [his]256-your grandfather life ; and [you]283-you 'll have a sup of the same broth some day . [You]283-you do n't keep a dog like that yelping cur for nothing ; and [I]179-the master 'll tell [the gamekeeper]1557-the gamekeeper to have [his]1557-the gamekeeper eye upon [you]283-you . '[179-the master] [Stephen]19-stephen stood motionless , watching [them]299-them down [the narrow path which led to [Botfield]23-botfield]300-the narrow path which led to botfield , until a rabbit started from beneath the hedge , and [Snip]29-snip , with a sharp , short bark of excitement , gave it chase in the direction of [the two men]301-the two men . [The master]179-the master paused , and , looking back , shook [his]179-the master stick threateningly at the motionless figure of [the boy]1434-the boy ; while [Thomas Wyley]36-mr. wyley threw a stone at the dog , which sent [him]29-snip back , yelping piteously , to [[his]29-snip young master]304-his young master 's feet . [Stephen]19-stephen clenched [his]19-stephen hands , and bit [his]19-stephen lips till the blood started , but [he]19-stephen did not move till the last glimpse of [[his]19-stephen foes]305-his foes had passed away from [the hillside]1428-the hillside . [Martha]22-martha had hidden [herself]22-martha in [the hut]1337-the hut while [they]301-the two men were present , for [she]22-martha had never spoken to [the dreaded master]308-the dreaded master ; but [she]22-martha could overhear [their]301-the two men loud and angry speeches , and now [she]22-martha came out and joined [Stephen]19-stephen . ' Well , [I]22-martha 'd have more spirit than to cry , '[22-martha] [she]22-martha said , as [Stephen]19-stephen brushed [his]19-stephen eyes with [his]19-stephen sleeve ; ' [I]22-martha 'd never have spoken so gingerly to [them]301-the two men , [the wizen - faced old rascals]1558-the wizen - faced old rascals . [The place]177-the place is [ours]1560-we , and [they]301-the two men ca n't turn [us]1560-we out . It 's no use to be cowed by [them]301-the two men , [Stephen]19-stephen . '[22-martha] ' [They]301-the two men can turn [me]19-stephen off the works , '[19-stephen] answered [Stephen]19-stephen sadly . ' And whatever shall [we]1560-we do then ? '[22-martha] asked [Martha]22-martha , in alarm . ' Still [I]22-martha reckon [you]19-stephen 'll say [we]1560-we are to love [those old wretches]1561-those old wretches . '[22-martha] ' The Book says so , '[19-stephen] replied [Stephen]19-stephen . ' Well , [I]22-martha wo n't set up to try to do it for one , '[22-martha] continued [Martha]22-martha decisively ; ' it 's not nature ; it 's being over good by half . [I]22-martha 'm[22-martha] willing to do [my]0-i duty by [you]309-you and [grandfather]1397-grandfather and [little Nan]34-little nan ; but that goes beyond [me]0-i . If [you]309-you 'd just give way , [Stevie]19-stephen , and give [them]311-them a good rating , [you]309-you 'd feel better after it . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know that , ' [he]0-i answered , walking gloomily towards the door . [He]0-i felt so much passion and anger within [him]0-i , that it did seem as if it would be a relief to utter some of the terrible oaths which [he]0-i heard frequently in [the pit]1478-the pit , and which had been familiar enough in [his]0-i own mouth a few months ago . But now other words , familiar from daily reading , the words that [he]0-i had repeated to [Tim]33-tim so short a time before , were being whispered , as it seemed , close by [his]0-i ear : '[0-i] Love [[your]309-you enemies]312-your enemies ; bless [them]312-your enemies that curse [you]309-you ; do good to [them]312-your enemies that hate [you]309-you ; pray for [them]312-your enemies that despitefully use [you]309-you , and persecute [you]309-you . ' There was a deadly conflict going on in [the boy]1434-the boy 's soul ; and [Martha]22-martha 's angry words were helping [the tempter]1564-the tempter . [He]0-i sat down despondently on the door - sill , and hid [his]0-i face in [his]0-i hands , while [he]0-i listened to [[his]0-i sister]191-his sister 's taunts against [his]0-i want of spirit , and [her]22-martha fears that [he]0-i would give up [[their]1566-their home]1567-their home for [his]0-i new notions . [He]0-i was about to answer [her]22-martha at last with the passion [she]22-martha was trying to provoke , when a soft little cheek was pressed against [his]0-i downcast head , and [little Nan]34-little nan lisped in [her]34-little nan broken words , '[0-i] [Me]0-i sleepy , [Stevie]19-stephen ; [me]0-i say " [[Our]313-us Father]199-our father , " and go to bed . ' [The child]1568-the child knelt down before [him]0-i , and laid [her]1568-the child folded hands upon [his]0-i knee , as [she]1568-the child had done every evening since [[his]0-i father]1392-his father died , while [he]0-i said the prayer , and [she]1568-the child repeated it slowly after [him]0-i . [He]0-i felt as though [he]0-i was praying for [himself]0-i . A feeling of deep earnestness came over [him]0-i ; and , though [his]0-i voice faltered as [he]0-i said softly , '[0-i] Forgive [us]313-us [our]313-us trespasses , as [we]313-us forgive [them]315-them that trespass against [us]313-us , ' it seemed as if there was a spirit in [his]0-i heart agreeing to the words , and giving [him]0-i power to say them . [He]0-i did not know then that '[0-i] the Spirit itself maketh intercession for [us]313-us with groanings which can not be uttered ; ' but while [he]0-i prayed with [little Nan]34-little nan , [he]0-i received great comfort and strength , though [he]0-i was ignorant of the source from whence [they]1570-they came . When [the child]1568-the child 's prayers were ended , [he]0-i roused [himself]0-i cheerfully to action ; and as long as the lingering twilight lasted , both [Stephen]19-stephen and [Martha]22-martha were busily at work in [the garden]1350-the garden . '[0-i] So [thee]316-thee 's [the only master here]317-the only master here , ' said [Tim]33-tim when [he]33-tim came up [the hill]1336-the hill next evening , according to [his]33-tim promise , to help [Stephen]19-stephen in [[his]179-the master garden]1574-his garden . '[316-thee] And [I]0-i 'm [the missis]1575-the missis , '[22-martha] chimed in [Martha]22-martha , ' but [I]22-martha ca n't say how long it may be afore [we]1576-we have to pack off ; '[22-martha] and [she]22-martha gave [Tim]33-tim a very long account of [the master]179-the master 's visit the day before , finishing [her]22-martha description of [Stephen]19-stephen 's conduct in a tone of mingled reproach and admiration : ' And [he]179-the master never said a single curse at [them]1576-we ! '[22-martha] ' Not when [they]1576-we were out of hearing ? '[33-tim] exclaimed [Tim]33-tim . ' [I]19-stephen could n't , '[19-stephen] answered [Stephen]19-stephen ; ' [I]19-stephen knew what [I]19-stephen ought to do then , if [I]19-stephen was n't quite sure about fighting [thee]19-stephen , [Tim]33-tim . [My]19-stephen chapter says , " Swear not at all ; " and " Let [your]19-stephen communication be [Yea]1577-yea , yea ; Nay , nay ; for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil . " '[19-stephen] ' What 's the meaning of that ? '[33-tim] asked [Tim]33-tim , opening [his]33-tim eyes widely . ' [Father]28-father said it meant [I]19-stephen was to stand to [my]19-stephen word like [a man]1421-a man , but not swear about it . If [I]19-stephen said Ay , to mean ay ; and if [I]19-stephen said No , to mean no , and stick to it . '[19-stephen] ' There 'd be no room for telling lies , [I]33-tim reckon , '[33-tim] said [Tim]33-tim reflectively . ' Of course not , '[19-stephen] replied [Stephen]19-stephen . ' That '[19-stephen] ud never answer down yonder , ' said [Tim]33-tim , nodding towards [the distant village]1579-the distant village . '[0-i] [I]0-i tell [thee]319-thee what , [lad]131-lad , [I]0-i 'll come and quarter with [thee]319-thee , and help [thee]319-thee to be [master]251-master . It ' ud be prime . Only maybe [the victuals]1580-the victuals would n't suit [me]0-i . Last Sunday , afore [[thy]319-thee father]1495-thy father 's buryin '[0-i] , [we]322-we 'd a dinner of duck and green peas , and leg of lamb , and custard pudden , and ale . [Martha]22-martha does n't get a dinner like that for [thee]319-thee , [I]0-i reckon . ' '[22-martha] No , ' answered [Stephen]19-stephen shortly . '[22-martha] Maybe it would n't suit . But what more is there in [thy]319-thee book ? ' asked [Tim]33-tim , whose curiosity was aroused ; and [Stephen]19-stephen , proud of [his]0-i new accomplishment,—a rare one in those days among [his]0-i own class,—would not lose the opportunity given [him]0-i by [Tim]33-tim 's inquiry for the display of [his]0-i learning . [He]0-i brought out [his]0-i Bible with alacrity , and read [his]0-i chapter in a loud , clear , sing - song tone , while [Tim]33-tim overlooked [him]0-i , with [his]33-tim red face growing redder , and [his]33-tim eyebrows arched in amazement ; and [Martha]22-martha , leaning against the door - post , glanced triumphantly at [his]33-tim wonder . Already , though [[his]33-tim father]1392-his father had been dead only a week , [Stephen]19-stephen began to miscall many of the harder words ; but [[his]19-stephen hearers]1583-his hearers were not critical , and the performance gave unbounded satisfaction . '[22-martha] That beats [me]0-i ! ' cried [Tim]33-tim . '[22-martha] What a headpiece [thee]323-thee must have , [Stephen]19-stephen ! But what does it all mean , [lad]131-lad ? Is it all English like ? ' '[22-martha] How can [I]0-i know ? ' answered [Stephen]19-stephen , somewhat sadly ; '[22-martha] there 's [nobody]147-nobody to learn [me]0-i now ; and it 's very hard . There 's [the Pharisees]326-the pharisees , [Tim]33-tim , and [Raca]38-raca ; [I]0-i do n't know who [they]327-they are . ' The conversation was stopped by [Martha]22-martha suddenly starting bolt upright , and dropping two or three hurried curtseys . [The boys]219-the boys looked up from [their]219-the boys book quickly , and saw [a young lady]1585-a young lady passing through [the wicket]1586-the wicket and coming up [the garden walk]1587-the garden walk , with a smile upon [her]1585-a young lady pleasant face as [she]1585-a young lady met [their]219-the boys gaze . '[328-my boys] [[My]0-i boys]328-my boys , ' [she]1585-a young lady said , in a soft , kindly voice , '[328-my boys] [I]0-i 've been sitting on [the bank yonder]329-the bank yonder , behind [[your]328-my boys cottage]330-your cottage ; and [I]0-i heard one of [you]328-my boys reading a chapter in the Bible . Which of [you]328-my boys was it ? ' '[331-him] It was [him]331-him , ' cried [Tim]33-tim and [Martha]22-martha together , pointing at [Stephen]19-stephen . '[331-him] And [you]328-my boys said [you]328-my boys had [no one]189-no one to teach [you]328-my boys , ' continued [the lady]1588-the lady . '[328-my boys] Now would [you]328-my boys learn well , if [I]0-i promised to teach [you]328-my boys ? ' [Stephen]19-stephen looked up speechlessly into the smiling face before [him]19-stephen . [He]19-stephen had never read of [the angels]1589-the angels , and scarcely knew that there were [such beings]1590-such beings ; but [he]19-stephen felt as if [this fair and sweet - looking lady , with [her]1588-the lady gentle voice , and the kindly eyes meeting [his]19-stephen own]1591-this fair and sweet - looking lady , with her gentle voice , and the kindly eyes meeting his own , was altogether of a different order to [themselves]1589-the angels . '[0-i] [I]0-i am [[Mr. Wyley]36-mr. wyley 's niece]333-mr. wyley 's niece , ' [she]1588-the lady added , '[0-i] and [I]0-i am come to live at [Botfield]23-botfield for a while . Could [you]328-my boys manage to come down to [[Mr. Wyley]36-mr. wyley 's house]334-mr. wyley 's house sometimes for a lesson ? ' '[328-my boys] Please , [ma'am]335-ma'am , ' said [Martha]22-martha , who was not at all afraid of speaking to [any lady]1592-any lady , though [she]22-martha dare not face [the master]179-the master , '[36-mr. wyley] [he]36-mr. wyley wants to turn [us]336-us out of [[our]336-us house]337-our house ; and [he]36-mr. wyley hates [Stephen]19-stephen , because [he]36-mr. wyley wo n't give it up : so [he]36-mr. wyley would n't let [you]328-my boys teach [him]36-mr. wyley anything . ' '[36-mr. wyley] Then [you]19-stephen are [Stephen Fern]19-stephen ? ' said [the lady]1588-the lady ; '[19-stephen] [I]0-i heard [[my]0-i uncle]338-my uncle talking about [you]19-stephen . [[Your]19-stephen father]248-your father was buried at [Longville church]340-longville church on Sunday . [I]0-i saw the funeral leave [the churchyard]341-the churchyard , and [I]0-i looked for some of [you]19-stephen to come in to the evening service . Now , [Stephen]19-stephen , do [you]19-stephen tell [me]0-i all about [your]19-stephen reason for not letting [[my]0-i uncle]338-my uncle buy [[your]19-stephen cottage]330-your cottage . ' Then [Stephen]19-stephen , with some hesitation , and a good deal of assistance from [Martha]22-martha , told the whole history of [[[his]19-stephen grandmother]1595-his grandmother 's settlement upon [the solitary hillside]1597-the solitary hillside]1596-his grandmother 's settlement upon the solitary hillside , only withholding the fact of [[his]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather 's transportation , because [Tim]33-tim was listening eagerly to every word . [Miss Anne]21-miss anne listened , too , with deep attention ; and once or twice the tears rose to [her]21-miss anne eyes as [she]21-miss anne heard of the weary labours and watchings of [the desolate woman]1599-the desolate woman ; and when [Stephen]19-stephen repeated [his]19-stephen resolution to work hard and constantly for the maintenance of [[his]19-stephen grandfather]1405-his grandfather and [little Nan]1601-little nan — '[19-stephen] Yes , [I]0-i will be [[your]344-your friend]345-your friend , ' [she]21-miss anne said , reaching out [her]21-miss anne hand to [him]19-stephen when [he]19-stephen had finished , '[344-your] even if [[my]0-i uncle]338-my uncle is [[your]344-your enemy]347-your enemy . [God]26-god has not given [me]0-i much power , but what [I]0-i have [I]0-i will use for [you]344-your ; and [you]344-your must go on striving to do right , [Stephen]19-stephen . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't read much , ' replied [Stephen]19-stephen anxiously , '[0-i] and [Martha]22-martha ca n't read at all ; but [I]0-i hope [we]348-we shall [all]349-all get safe to [heaven]226-heaven ! ' '[0-i] Knowing how to read will not take [us]348-we to [heaven]226-heaven , ' said [Miss Anne]21-miss anne , smiling , '[0-i] but doing the will of [God]26-god from the heart ; and the will of [God]26-god is that [we]348-we should believe in [the Lord Jesus]39-christ , and follow in [His]39-christ steps . ' '[26-god] Yes , [ma'am]335-ma'am , ' answered [Stephen]19-stephen ; '[0-i] [my]0-i chapter says , " Whosoever shall break one of these least commandments , and shall teach [men]1482-men so , shall be called the least in [the kingdom of heaven]354-the kingdom of heaven : but whosoever shall do and teach [them]1482-men , the same shall be called great in the kingdom of [heaven]226-heaven . " ' '[19-stephen] [Stephen]19-stephen , [you]19-stephen know [your]19-stephen chapter well , ' said [Miss Anne]21-miss anne . '[19-stephen] [I]0-i do n't know anything else , ' [he]0-i answered ; '[0-i] so [I]0-i am always studying at that in [my]0-i head , up here and down in the pit . ' '[0-i] [He]0-i 's always mighty solid over [his]0-i work , [ma'am]335-ma'am , ' said [Tim]33-tim , pulling the front lock of [his]33-tim red hair , as [he]33-tim spoke to [the young lady]1602-the young lady . '[0-i] [Stephen]19-stephen , do [you]19-stephen know that [you]19-stephen have a namesake in the Bible ? ' asked [Miss Anne]21-miss anne . '[19-stephen] No , sure ! ' exclaimed [Stephen]19-stephen eagerly . '[19-stephen] It was the name of [a man who had many enemies]357-a man who had many enemies , only because [he]357-a man who had many enemies loved [the Lord Jesus]39-christ ; and at last [they]358-they hated [him]357-a man who had many enemies so much as to kill [him]357-a man who had many enemies . [He]357-a man who had many enemies was [the very first person who ever suffered death for [the Lord]360-the lord 's sake]359-the very first person who ever suffered death for the lord 's sake . Give [me]0-i [your]19-stephen Bible , and [I]0-i will read to [you]19-stephen how [he]357-a man who had many enemies died . ' [Miss Anne]21-miss anne 's voice was very low and soft , like sweet music , as [she]21-miss anne read these verses : '[0-i] And [they]358-they stoned [Stephen]19-stephen , calling upon [God]26-god , and saying , [Lord Jesus]39-christ , receive [my]0-i spirit . And [he]19-stephen kneeled down , and cried with a loud voice , [Lord]361-lord , lay not this sin to [their]358-they charge . And when [he]19-stephen had said this , [he]19-stephen fell asleep . ' [Stephen]19-stephen listened breathlessly , and [his]19-stephen face glowed with intense interest ; but [he]19-stephen was not [a boy of ready speech]1603-a boy of ready speech , and , before [he]19-stephen could utter a word , [Tim]33-tim burst in before [him]19-stephen with a question , '[19-stephen] Please , is there a [Tim]33-tim in the Bible ? ' [he]33-tim asked . '[33-tim] Yes , ' answered [Miss Anne]21-miss anne , smiling again ; '[33-tim] [he]33-tim was [a young man who knew the Bible from [his]33-tim youth]362-a young man who knew the bible from his youth . ' '[33-tim] That ai n't [me]0-i , however , ' said [Tim]33-tim in a despondent tone . '[0-i] There is nothing now to prevent [you]363-you beginning to know it , ' continued [Miss Anne]21-miss anne . '[0-i] Listen : as [Stephen]19-stephen can not come to [me]0-i at [Botfield]23-botfield , [you]363-you shall meet [me]0-i in [the Red Gravel Pit]364-the red gravel pit at nine o'clock on a Sunday morning as long as the summer lasts , and [I]0-i will teach [you]363-you all . Bring little [Nan]21-miss anne with [you]363-you , [Stephen]19-stephen . ' Down the same narrow green pathway trodden by the feet of [[Stephen]19-stephen 's angry master]1604-stephen 's angry master and [[his]19-stephen brother]1521-his brother the evening before , [they]363-you now watched [the little light figure of [the young lady]1602-the young lady]1606-the little light figure of the young lady , as [she]1602-the young lady slowly vanished out of [their]363-you sight . When the gleaming of [her]21-miss anne dress was quite lost , [Stephen]19-stephen rubbed [his]19-stephen eyes for a moment , and then turned to [Martha]22-martha and [Tim]33-tim . '[19-stephen] Is [she]21-miss anne [a real woman]365-a real woman , dost think ? ' [he]19-stephen asked . '[365-a real woman] [A real woman]365-a real woman ! ' repeated [Martha]22-martha rather scornfully ; '[21-miss anne] of course [she]21-miss anne is ; and it 's a real silk gown [she]21-miss anne had on , [I]0-i can tell [thee]367-thee . [Spirits]40-spirits do n't go about in silk gowns and broad daylight , never as [I]0-i heard tell of , [lad]131-lad . ' At the entrance of the lane leading down to [the works at [Botfield]23-botfield]1608-the works at botfield there stood [a small square building]1609-a small square building , which was used as [the weighing - house]1610-the weighing - house for the coal and lime fetched from [the pits]1611-the pits , and as [the pay - office]1612-the pay - office on the reckoning Saturday , which came once a fortnight . Upon the Saturday evening after [his]19-stephen interview with [the master]179-the master , [Stephen]19-stephen loitered in [the lane]1614-the lane with a very heavy heart , afraid of facing [Mr. Wyley]36-mr. wyley , lest [he]19-stephen should receive the sentence of dismission from [the pit]1478-the pit . [He]19-stephen did not know what [he]19-stephen could turn [his]19-stephen hand to if [he]19-stephen should be discharged from what had been [his]19-stephen work since [he]19-stephen was eight years old ; for even if [he]19-stephen could get a place in [one of [the farmhouses about as [waggoner 's boy]1618-waggoner 's boy]1617-the farmhouses about as waggoner 's boy]1616-one of the farmhouses about as waggoner 's boy , [he]19-stephen would not earn more than three shillings a week ; and how very little that would do towards providing food for [the three mouths at [home]125-home]1619-the three mouths at home !
